Just Cause 3 delivers an open-world built for destruction and traversal rather than tight mission structure. The core loop depends on mobility, explosives, and territorial disruption. The game encourages improvisation through its tools rather than scripted solutions.

Traversal is the standout system. The wingsuit, parachute, and grappling hook create a fast and readable flow across large distances. Movement feels consistent and supports rapid entry and exit from combat zones. This mobility defines the rhythm of play more than any weapon does.

Combat favors spectacle over precision. Explosive chains, destructible bases, and vehicle hijacking create high output with low friction. Enemies provide enough resistance to maintain pressure but do not challenge strategic planning. The design aims for continuous motion rather than tactical depth.

The world is large and segmented into clear capture targets. Each region becomes a checklist of structures to destroy. The repetition is intentional and supports a steady progression curve, though the loop can flatten for players who prefer varied mission types.

Narrative content is minimal. Characters and plot serve as scaffolding for the action but remain secondary. The story moves at a predictable pace and stays unobtrusive.

Performance varies. Large explosions, dense effects, and heavy physics can stress hardware, though general traversal remains stable. Loading times are moderate and acceptable for an open world of this scale.

Overall Just Cause 3 is a systems-forward sandbox focused on mobility and high-volume destruction. It provides reliable momentum for players who want constant action without complex structure.

The alerts that let you know an uncollected vehicle is nearby are incredibly helpful, and while most of them are easy to snag, a few turn into physics puzzles of their own.  For example: [spoiler]air-lifting a boat out of a pond with the tether grapple hook and a helicopter just to get it to open water where the delivery dock is[/spoiler].  All in all, nothing in this game felt like a chore.

This game is a good sequel to Just Cause 2. I didn't play the first iteration of the series.
Also didn't play the sequel to this, which seems to have much less praise from the community.

I miss some things from Just Cause 2 here, like the helicopter dynamics, the "dodge" roll. The helicopter driving is much more "arcade-ish" in this version than it was in the previous, I liked how they behaved more "realisticly" in 2. And there's simply no dodging at all. You are always a sitting duck taking bullets head on, but somehow surviving lots of hits.

The game story missions (so far) are cool, and the story missions are really good to get up to speed and understand the game mechanics.

The way that the game works now, once a settlement is "cleared", it becomes "allied" with easy access and making it easy to escape tough encounters too. I like this more than how it was in 2, where only military installations would lift security for easy access to goodies.

I couldn't get the hang of plane driving. Similarly, the introduced "glider" mechanics is not for me. In 2, planes were not as useful, but I could play around hitting some targets in bases. In 3, I could barely take off a plane. Which brings to a next topic: the key bindings.

Customizing the key bindings is not great at all in this version. In 2 there was already an issue with game keys being "linked" between car-foot-heli. Such that if you changed one control for flying, it would affect, for instance, jumping when on foot. This became even worse in 3. I took a look in the configuration file (which thankfully is something one can read in v3 -- v2 was binary), and (for what I could notice) there's no separate key binding for those "linked" controls.

Back to some positive aspects, the graphics are great. Vehicle damage is cool (how they visually are affected as they are hit or hit stuff). But again, the other cars explode too easily, in simple crashes.

Now we can fill the car we're driving with allies to help (a bit) in confrontation. It's funny to see them filling up the car and also the idle chatting. Yet, some vehicles (like boat with turrets) don't support calling in help (at least I couldn't find a way to), and there's a vehicle that once the doors are open they never close again.

Enemy ships feel overkill here. Their accuracy seems too high both on foot and in a vehicle. It was much more fun to deal with ships in 2. But now we got fancy new ship kinds to drive and wreak havoc about.

All in all, the game is even more addictive than 2. In 2, I quickly became bored of taking settlements, while 3 gives a sense of accomplishment every taken settlement and it's not much a treasure hunting like it is in 2.

The game is really good to "discharge anger" or something like it, as it is super-duper-not-punishing, we can just hop in destroy stuff and relieve the real life angers. The 3 is even less punishing than 2! Only exception to places "locked" with "FOW" (fog of war?) where overwhelming mechanics are placed to force the player to follow certain story missions and lift the tension in the area.

The game is fun, but my goodness gracious was there a lot of barriers to that enjoyment, and the only reason I actually dedicated the time to finish it was because I'm trying to clear my games backlog, otherwise, based purely on fun vs. frustration, I would have never touched it again. If you want the succinct version, JC2 is the genuine article, fun, engaging, right tone, excellent setting. JC3 feels like the backwards cap wearing 40 year old uncle who tries way too hard to be cool.

It's hard to break this into good and bad, as it seems every good part about this game has its bad side. As most people have said, the moment to moment gameplay can be fun, with the typical JC blow everything up in sight gameply. But f me if the controls don't just suck. Where to begin. Rico often feels like he's moving around in molasses, rather than the fluid control of JC2. The driving and flying is just confusing, it's impossible to get a good handling feel. The only way I can describe it is arcadey on steroids, and sometimes you'll be braking for a nice gentle turn and the cars/motorbikes will do a full 90 degree turn since you've pressed some combination of controls. It's almost like they didn't QA test the controls enough. And the way they force Rico to walk on aircraft, which, if you're doing boat based missions, welcome to the most dangerous enemy in the game. Hit-scanning machine gunners on boats that will kill you in seconds since you can't move much faster than a sloth. Or the way they don't let you walk off edges (it literally stops you, then you have to press jump if you actually want to jump off an edge) - this really breaks the fluidity of controls. I could go on, but just to say, the controls and handling of Rico contribute a great deal to the frustration.

The setting is also very beautiful, though I wish they set more of the game on the last island, which seemed to have more interesting biomes than idyllic Mediterranean seaside #36, but given the same-ness of the first two islands, liberations of settlements becomes a real grind towards the end. 

The minigames can be fun - at first. But the way they locked a lot of the fun elements behind these 'gears' that you earn, and some essential gear, means this locks the more fun gameplay behind a lot of these mini games, contributing to that frustrating grind, where JC2 gave you a lot more freedom to just enjoy the insanity of the game from the get-go. It does tie well into the gameplay loop, and provides a somewhat fun distraction. When combined with the absolute junk controls however, this can really become a drag. 

Finally, the story and characterisation just really plays into that 'try-hard uncle' metaphor the most. JC2 had this wonderful self aware ridiculousness to it, whereas the tone of JC3 seems a bit all over the place. I mean, I feel like the developers are aware of the subtle irony of liberating a settlement by completely destroying it. I would love to say things like 'I have come to liberate you!' just before launching a missile into a crowded street, or creating a gordian knot of civilians and their cars using the grappling hooks until they explode. So the premise of the games absolutely ridiculous. I feel like they kind of tried to shy away from this with the story, tried to make it a little serious which I think was a bad choice. As for the characters, I don't know how, but over the course of the game I came to hate absolutely every character in it. Maybe apart from Annika and Teo, who barely featured in it, but everybody, including Rico, just were so annoying. The way he would shout 'Boomgift!' every time you threw a grenade... I mean, it just felt totally lame coming from Rico. I liked in JC2, where he was always completely serious, and the game was ridiculous around him, if that makes sense. Dimah is annoying as hell. Mario tries to be funny, but, yeah, everything just falls flat. 

So, overall, the gameplay was fun enough to keep me hooked, but getting there in the end was a really frustrating experience. I do recommend the game (even though I've thumbed it down), but barely, since I would love a Just Cause that feels like a Just Cause game, and not trying to pretend to be something else, like I feel they were trying to do with this game.
